hook.text: 17th-century Netherlands: no king, no pope commissioning art. Instead, prosperous merchants bought paintings for their homes. For the first time, art served the middle class â€” and it changed what artists painted.

buildup.text: New genres flourished: landscapes (Ruisdael), still life (Heda), genre scenes (Vermeer), and group portraits (Hals). Paintings showed everyday life: kitchens, markets, taverns, flowers, and light through windows.

discovery.text: Vermeer mastered light like no one before: soft daylight through a window, illuminating a woman reading a letter. His paintings feel like frozen moments â€” quiet, intimate, luminous. Just 34 known paintings, each a jewel.

twist.text: Still life paintings (vanitas) looked beautiful but carried hidden messages: skulls = death, wilting flowers = fading beauty, timepieces = passing time. Behind the lovely surface: 'Remember, you will die.'

climax.text: Rembrandt: the giant. His self-portraits span his life â€” from confident young artist to weathered old man. His late works use thick, visible paint and emotional depth that wouldn't be matched for 200 years.

punchline.text: The Dutch proved that art didn't need gods or kings. Everyday life, beautifully observed, is enough.

quiz.question: What was unique about the art market during the Dutch Golden Age?
